channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Review: Boss Level offers a witty, bloody take on the time-loop trope
item.description: Everyone seems to be having a blast in Joe Carnahan’s over-the-top sci-fi thriller.

item.title: Mother to Earth: When an NES prototype lands on eBay and inspires a documentary
item.description: Kickstarted movies can go down pretty narrow rabbit holes, but this is some real hyperfocus.

item.title: How to find a COVID-19 vaccine appointment in your area
item.description: Vaccination rollout has been a challenge across the US. These tips should help.

item.title: Researchers think a planet lost its original atmosphere, built a new one
item.description: Imaging the atmosphere finds a combination of chemicals that shouldn’t be there.

item.title: Federal investigators blast Tesla, call for stricter safety standards
item.description: NTSB blames NHTSA and Tesla for a deadly 2019 Autopilot crash in Florida.

item.title: The Code Breaker is the CRISPR chronicle you need to read
item.description: Q�A: Walter Isaacson’s account is a thrilling tale of scientific discovery.

item.title: Exchange servers first compromised by Chinese hackers hit with ransomware
item.description: As if Exchange users didn’t already have enough to worry about, they have this.

item.title: “Shocking” genetic data suggest Ebola lurked in survivor for 5-6 years
item.description: Ebola virus is known to persist in some survivors—but not for this long.

item.title: Qualcomm smartphones are the next devices to get hit by chip shortage
item.description: Qualcomm faces pandemic shortages, Huawei’s sanctions, and Texas power problems.

item.title: US lawmakers propose Australia-style bill for media, tech negotiations
item.description: Both Democrats and Republicans want to do something. Maybe not the same something.

item.title: Scientists solve another piece of the puzzling Antikythera mechanism
item.description: “Our reconstruction fits all the evidence… gleaned from the extant remains to date."

item.title: AT&T promises fiber-to-the-home expansion in 90 metro areas this year
item.description: Tens of millions in AT�T territory lack fiber—3 million should get it in 2021.

item.title: HBO Max will get a cheaper, ad-supported tier in June
item.description: HBO Max will also launch in 21 new territories in Europe by the end of 2021.

item.title: Short-selling firm accuses Lordstown of exaggerating truck pre-orders
item.description: Lordstown CEO claimed to have 50,000 “very serious orders.”

item.title: Drivers are 24% more likely to speed when using adaptive cruise control
item.description: IIHS studied 40 Boston-area drivers to characterize speeding behavior.

item.title: Ballsy vasectomy ads get foul call from NCAA
item.description: Though urologists aim to get patients shooting blanks, NCAA is still playing zone.

item.title: Apple alleges ex-MacBook Pro designer leaked secret details to reporter
item.description: Apple: Ex-employee leaked future hardware products, sought favors from reporter.

item.title: Chrome 89 increases desktop memory efficiency with PartitionAlloc
item.description: Decreasing RAM usage is more important than ever, with The Great Suspender gone.

item.title: Ancient massacre site yields its victims’ DNA
item.description: The ancient DNA study raises more questions than it answers.

item.title: The moments we realized the pandemic would change everything
item.description: COVID-19, one year later: Ars staff looks back on… truly something else.

item.title: Rocket Report: China debuts new booster, SpaceX eyeing Indonesia launch site?
item.description: “This is a game-changer for South African space science.”

item.title: Tossing vaccine priority list, Biden tells states to open eligibility by May 1
item.description: In “war-time” effort, all adult Americans will have access to vaccine by May 1.

item.title: Critics fume after Github removes exploit code for Exchange vulnerabilities
item.description: Microsoft-owned Github pulls down proof-of-concept code posted by researcher.

item.title: Google Maps introduces a way for users to add and edit roads (again)
item.description: Maps is also getting a new way to upload photos to place listings.

item.title: Facebook asks judge to toss antitrust suits, claiming no consumer harm
item.description: Facebook’s arguments boil down to “no we didn’t, and you have no standing.”

item.title: Sony’s DualSense controller for the PlayStation 5 is $10 off today
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Mario games, Peacock, and internal SSDs.

item.title: Putting Roblox’s incredible $45 billion IPO in context
item.description: Wednesday’s stock offering values the user-created game platform higher than EA.

item.title: Democratic-led Congress gets serious about universal broadband funding
item.description: Congress OKs $7 billion for broadband and has another $94 billion teed up.

item.title: Bethesda’s leap to Xbox Game Pass adds 12 classics: Oblivion, more [Updated]
item.description: Spencer clarifies exclusivity: “Great exclusive games… where Game Pass exists.”

item.title: New Oppo smartphone has a 60x microscope camera
item.description: The Oppo Find X3 Pro can zoom way, way in on objects.

item.title: Blue Screen of the day—update crashes Windows 10 PCs on print
item.description: It’s not always DNS… sometimes it’s printers.

item.title: Canoo’s electric pickup might be the coolest electric truck yet
item.description: Fold-out worktables, modular storage, and an extending bed all feature.

item.title: Microsoft Edge is dead—long live Microsoft Edge
item.description: To the four of you who were using legacy Edge, we extend our condolences.

item.title: A Russian ISP confirms Roskomnadzor’s Twitter-blocking blooper
item.description: Our source demonstrated heavy throttling of microsoft.com, not just t.co.

item.title: Why Big Tech is facing regulatory threats from Australia to Arizona
item.description: The era of Silicon Valley exceptionalism is over.

item.title: There’s a vexing mystery surrounding the 0-day attacks on Exchange servers
item.description: A half-dozen groups exploiting the same 0-days is unusual, if not unprecedented.

item.title: Researchers measure the gravity exerted by a 90 milligram object
item.description: We’ve measured the pull between two gold spheres, each 2 millimeters across.

item.title: The googly eyes of the mantis shrimp inspire new optical sensors
item.description: Small enough to fit on a smartphone, capable of hyperspectral and polarimetric imaging.

item.title: Twitter sues Texas AG to stop “retaliatory” content-moderation probe
item.description: Texas targeted Twitter because of protected content moderation, suit claims.

item.title: Adobe Photoshop now runs natively on M1 Macs
item.description: Other M1-native apps that hit this week include 1Password and DaVinci Resolve.

item.title: Amazon Vesta project seems to be ramping up for production
item.description: Do you want a wheeled camera following you around the house? Amazon bets “yes.”

item.title: Comcast scrambled to fix mistake that cut some users’ upload speeds by 20%
item.description: Comcast upgrade backfired, reducing uploads from 20 to 16Mbps until it was fixed.

item.title: Strapping a giant teddy bear to a car in the name of highway safety
item.description: Familiarity breeds awareness when it comes to advanced driver assists.

item.title: The Asus ROG Phone 5 has 18GB of RAM, two USB ports, crazy rear display
item.description: Asus' “gaming” phone has 18GB of RAM, a fan attachment, and shoulder buttons.

item.title: Russian attempt to throttle Twitter appears to backfire
item.description: Begin with 99 problems. Solve one with a regex. You now have 108 problems…

item.title: This sea slug can lose its head and regenerate new body in three weeks
item.description: She severs sea slugs down by the seashore… or rather, Sayaka Mitoh does so in the lab.

item.title: Denuvo brings its gaming anti-tampering technology to the PS5
item.description: Middleware promises to protect “fairness and fun” as well as developer revenues.

item.title: Car groups throw spanner in works of EU’s hydrogen drive
item.description: Industry pours cold water on idea hydrogen can vie with battery power to replace ICEs.

item.title: COVID herd immunity may be unlikely—winter surges could “become the norm”
item.description: Despite a lot of uncertainty, researchers lay out five ways to prepare for the worst.

item.title: Rocket Lab will directly challenge SpaceX with its proposed Neutron launcher
item.description: “We’re in this for the long haul.”

item.title: From buggies to buses, the first Black-owned US automaker did what few others dared
item.description: Few of its products remain, but C.R. Patterson � Sons was an industry trailblazer.

item.title: Hackers access security cameras inside Cloudflare, jails, and hospitals
item.description: Cloud-based camera service Verkada exposed hardcoded password—and its customers.

item.title: As a crop, cannabis has enormous carbon emissions
item.description: Ironically, growing it in a controlled environment has a huge environmental impact.

item.title: Want some Ryzen in your Surface? Rumor has it Microsoft does, too
item.description: If you prefer a Surface with a heavier multicore punch, we’ve got hopeful news.
